html:
** Amazon.com Inc AMZN.O said on Thursday it was raising the price of its annual U.S. Prime subscriptions by 17%, as it looks to offset higher costs for shipping and wages that it expects to persist this year (Full Story)


AWS STRENGTH BALANCES ECOMMERCE HEADWINDS

** J.P.Morgan ("overweight", PT: $4500) says macro pressures will remain and Omicron will create further disruption in 2022, but with greater normalization AMZN can deal with elevated labor costs

** "We continue to expect revenue growth to re-accelerate beginning in Q2 as comps ease and Prime 1-day/same-day benefits increase, and we also believe AMZN's investments will slow following 2 heavy years, creating room for margin expansion" - JPM

** KeyBanc ("overweight", PT: $4000) says "normalized" growth will allow AMZN to focus on becoming more efficient and innovative

** "That's not to say that AMZN's innovation focus suffered, per se, but that the focus on running "flat out" during COVID likely disrupted the normal cadence of improvement within AMZN" - KeyBanc

** CFRA ("buy") expects macro headwinds could continue in the first and second half, with another year of heavy investments in headcount, cloud, streaming content, devices, fulfillment, etc

** "Still, we see notable bright spots in Amazon Web Services and digital advertising growth, among other areas" - CFRA

** Canaccord Genuity ("buy", PT: $2400) says AMZN faces another difficult comp in Q1, although growth should pick up throughout 2022 with improving supply chain headwinds

** Impressive momentum from AMZN's high-margin AWS and advertising businesses can uplift investor sentiment this year - brokerage


(Reporting by Aniruddha Ghosh in Bengaluru)

(( Aniruddha.Ghosh@thomsonreuters.com ; 91 83 83 81 2416; ))
